Crimes.Crime_Name: Willful blindness to crimes against humanity
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1F of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted knowledge of torture but did not participate; was a low-ranking officer who avoided involvement in abuses
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Deserted Sri Lankan Police Force in 1997
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: CRDD initially excluded based on willful blindness; Federal Court found decision unreasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admission of knowledge of torture, rank and role in police force
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence of personal participation or knowing complicity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible fear of persecution by both LTTE and government forces
Crimes.Outcome: Case referred to new panel for re-determination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Personal and knowing participation required for exclusion under Article 1F
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere presence or willful blindness insufficient for exclusion; no proof of active complicity

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Hussenu claimed refugee protection but was deemed inadmissible due to ELF membership; argued lack of knowledge and cessation of involvement
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged ignorance of ELF's terrorist activities
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of procedural fairness regarding exemption under s. 34(2)

Crimes.Evidence_Used: Membership in ELF, organization's engagement in hijackings and sabotage
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence provided to support cessation or exemption under s. 34(2)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on availability of exemption information
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds to believe membership in terrorist organization
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No duty on Minister to inform of s. 34(2) exemption; exemption publicly available
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division, Federal Court on review

Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistency of testimony, lack of corroborating evidence for disengagement

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Constitutional duty to consult Aboriginal groups
Outcome: Canada breached its duty to consult
Grounds_for_Claim: Overlapping land claims affecting Treaty and Aboriginal rights
Decision_Outcome: Court declared breach of duty; ordered immediate and substantive consultations
Credibility: Established through court recognition of duty to consult
State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate – consultation delayed until after agreement in principle
Risk_Nature: Potential infringement of Aboriginal and Treaty rights
Victim_Basis: Aboriginal group with asserted overlapping land claims

Crimes.Crime_Name: Complicity in the commission of crimes against humanity
Nature_of_Acts: Advocacy of non-violence, but organizational ties to violent acts
Evidence_Credibility: Evidence shows TNA collaborated with LTTE
Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of proof of voluntary contribution to crimes
Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable grounds for belief required under IRPA
Consequences_of_Action: Initial finding of inadmissibility quashed on judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility for membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Membership in TNA with ties to LTTE
Decision_Outcome: Upheld under s. 34(1)(f), quashed under s. 35(1)(a)
Institutional_Action: Judicial review of Immigration Division decision
Risk_Factor: Association with organization linked to terrorism
Risk_Nature: Security risk due to organizational affiliation

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Employment discrimination and failure to accommodate
Grounds_for_Claim: Disability discrimination and lack of reasonable accommodation
Legal_Framework: Administrative law and human rights law
Institutional_Action: Investigation by the Canadian Human Rights Commission
Government_Body_or_Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court
Individual_Status_or_Claim: Person with a disability seeking workplace accommodation
State_Protection_Assessment: Adequate investigation conducted by the Commission
Credibility: Claim not supported by evidence according to investigator
Legal_Provision: Section 5 and Section 10 of the Canadian Human Rights Act
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate by the reviewing court
Risk_Nature: Non-material adverse impact due to lack of accommodation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 70(5)(c) requires an adjudicator to find a conviction for an offence with a ten-year imprisonment term
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial Review of Appeal Division's dismissal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Adjudicator found conviction with over six months imprisonment but did not assess ten-year term requirement
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On adjudicator to determine eligibility under s. 70(5)(c)
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Only an adjudicator can determine if the offence carries a potential ten-year sentence under s. 70(5)(c)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of jurisdiction due to failure to meet s. 70(5)(c) requirements
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Referred back for determination on merits
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction under s. 27(1)(d)(i), no finding on ten-year sentence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to allow appeal on merits

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to establish conviction with ten-year sentence under s. 70(5)(c)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Referred back for redetermination on merits
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Appeal Division dismissed appeal for lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Applicant subject to deportation as alleged public danger
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Assessed as public danger under s. 70(5)
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Prior conviction for serious personal injury offence
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed inadequate due to public danger finding

Crime_Type: Violations of Immigration Regulations
Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant applied for permanent residency; claimed work experience under NOC 4162; submitted financial documents deemed unreliable
Residency_Compliance: N/A - application was rejected prior to granting of status
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged lack of credible financial documentation
Procedural_Issue: Visa officer failed to assess work experience under applicant's chosen NOC category (4162); did not provide opportunity to respond to concerns about document credibility
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of valid work experience under correct NOC code
Credibility_Assessment: Financial documents found not credible; no chance given to address concerns
Decision_Outcome: Application rejected due to insufficient work experience points and unreliable financial documents
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of application by a different visa officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer erred in applying NOC categories and breached procedural fairness by not allowing applicant to respond
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crime_Type: Violations of Immigration Regulations
Legal_Provision_Violated: Rule 30 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules
Application_Facts: Applicant's claim for refugee protection was dismissed due to excluded evidence; late-filed documents were refused without assessing relevance, probative value, or due diligence.
Procedural_Issue: Board breached rules of natural justice by refusing to accept late-filed documents without considering Rule 30 factors; denial persisted even after counsel attempted to file a smaller subset.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Late submission of documents; Board failed to assess relevance, probative value, and due diligence under Rule 30.
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case remitted for redetermination by a different panel.
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim with consideration of late-filed documents
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 30 of the Refugee Protection Division Rules: relevance, probative value, and due diligence in late document filings
Decision_Rationale: The Board failed to follow procedural fairness by not applying the required factors under Rule 30 when rejecting late documents, constituting a breach of natural justice.

Crime_Type: Violations of Immigration Regulations
Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed statelessness and risk of persecution in Pakistan
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application filed challenging IRB's decision
Evidence_Used: IRB considered evidence regarding ability to acquire Pakistani citizenship and lack of credible persecution risk
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting statelessness or persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims found not credible by IRB
Relief_Sought: Overturning of IRB decision on refugee status
Decision_Rationale: Applicant could acquire Pakistani citizenship and failed to provide sufficient evidence of persecution

Crime_Type: Violations of Immigration Regulations
Application_Facts: Parmar applied as an assisted relative with a job offer but was rejected due to insufficient points, lack of relevant experience, and concerns about personal suitability.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review initiated by Parmar to challenge the visa officer's decision
Evidence_Used: Job offer, application documents, assessment of points for SVP, occupational demand, and personal suitability
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient points, lack of relevant experience, concerns about personal suitability
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility or suitability assessment by visa officer
Relief_Sought: Overturning of visa officer's rejection decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to reverse the refusal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment under Immigration Act and Regulations including point system and personal suitability
Decision_Rationale: The visa officer did not err in assessing that Parmar failed to meet the required points and qualifications; Federal Court found no error in the decision

Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on senior government position
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant held a senior position in the Rwandan government during a period of systematic human rights violations; worked closely with individuals implicated in genocide
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment of procedural fairness in immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Organizational hierarchy data, association with implicated individuals
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Senior role in government involved in human rights violations meets criteria for inadmissibility under section 35(1)(b)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility for violating human or international rights

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on association with human rights-violating government

Crimes.Outcome: Inadmissible due to senior official status during human rights violations

Crimes.Targeted_Group: Tutsi population and political opponents during Rwandan genocide

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a prescribed senior official in the service of a government engaging in systematic or gross human rights violations
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility as a prescribed senior official in a rights-violating regime
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Paragraph 35(1)(b) and section 16(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Found inadmissible due to senior role in Rwandan government

Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights law

Crimes.Risk_Nature: Gross and systematic human rights violations

Crime_Type: Property Crimes
Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness, errors in law or fact in visa denial
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of applicant's ties to Pakistan, intent to immigrate
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unfairness or error
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's credibility regarding intent and ties to home country
Legal_Rule: Visa officers must follow procedural fairness and base decisions on evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of procedural fairness, use of extrinsic evidence, incorrect legal standards
Key_Evidence_Considered: Ties to Pakistan, employment authorization request, immigration intent indicators
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration and refugee protection laws
Defendant_Response: Visa officer's decision was reasonable and evidence-based
Legal_Provision: Sections of Immigration and Refugee Protection Act relating to work permits and admissibility

Crime_Type: Violent Crimes
Evidence_Sufficiency: Substantial circumstantial evidence supports the conviction
Evidence_Credibility: New expert reports questioned use of accelerant but did not rule out arson
Credibility_Assessment: Minister considered evidence and found conviction sound

Crime_Type: Violent Crimes
Evidence_Sufficiency: Substantial circumstantial evidence supports the conviction despite new expert evidence
Evidence_Credibility: New expert reports challenged accelerant use but did not rule out arson
Credibility_Assessment: Minister found the conviction sound after reviewing all evidence

Crime_Type: Violations of Immigration Regulations
Governing_Law: Charter of Rights and Freedoms (s. 7, s. 2(a))
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status based on religious persecution; Member questioned depth of Christian knowledge and dismissed Canadian church involvement
Procedural_Issue: Failure to apply rigorous standard for implausibility
Lack of fair process in assessing religious belief
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No objective standards used to assess religious knowledge
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on subjective religious testing
Outcome: Referred back to a different panel
Decision_Rationale: RPD decision flawed due to improper religious questioning and failure to consider all evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in assessing the genuineness of the applicant's marriage
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case remanded for reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found inconsistencies in interview answers but some were minor
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence was strong; inconsistencies in interview responses
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section related to genuineness of marriage under IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage sponsorship application denied due to doubts about genuineness
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of transparency and justification in officer's decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to adequately justify rejection of applicant's explanations
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Strong documentary evidence downplayed despite minor inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Marriage must be genuine and not entered into for immigration purposes
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and consistency of relationship evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - compliance with removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to leave Canada per removal order and applied for permanent residence under spousal class
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with removal order
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Doubts about genuineness of marriage in spousal sponsorship application
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer inadequately explained rejection of applicant’s justifications
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minor inconsistencies not properly contextualized; lack of explanation for rejecting evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted marriage genuineness based on inconsistent answers
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case sent back for new assessment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status under spousal class
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Lack of transparency and inadequate justification rendered decision unreasonable

Crimes.Violation_Type: Potential overstaying of temporary resident status
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a truck driver with family in India; applied for third work permit; assessed as having insufficient English proficiency (IELTS Band 4); considered young, single, and mobile raising concerns about intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Concerns about compliance with conditions of stay and intent to depart after permit expiration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Used: IELTS scores, job duties, personal circumstances (age, marital status, family ties in home country)
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of language proficiency and weak ties to home country
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's intent to leave Canada not sufficiently established
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question and overturning of refusal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded risk of overstaying due to personal factors and inadequate English for job requirements
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work permit refusal based on eligibility concerns
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of visa officer's refusal due to language proficiency and likelihood of departure
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review denied, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's language ability and intent to leave Canada questioned
Crimes.Evidence_Type: IELTS test results, job description, personal background
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPR s.200 – Work permit eligibility criteria
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient English proficiency (Band 4 vs required Band 5), risk of overstaying
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Language proficiency and applicant’s personal circumstances indicating high mobility and low incentive to return
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review before the Federal Court
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: General language demands of occupation, not just specific employer duties
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found by court; officer considered relevant factors
Crimes.Application_Factor: Third work permit application, prior experience as truck driver

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer err in refusing the applicant's work permit based on insufficient evidence and procedural fairness?
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court allowed the judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s intent to leave Canada post-expiry was doubted due to weak ties and financial incentives
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Requirement to demonstrate intent to leave Canada after work permit expiry
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Perceived weak familial ties and high salary incentive in Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Intent to leave Canada after temporary stay
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide opportunity to respond to concerns
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of family and employment ties in home country
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family ties, employment abroad, financial incentives

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of procedural fairness/Breach of natural justice in immigration context
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer breach principles of natural justice by not interviewing the applicant before denying the work permit?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Principles of Natural Justice and Procedural Fairness in Administrative Law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Concerns about higher salary in Canada and limited family ties were used without disclosure
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside; case referred to another officer
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility, but officer must follow fair process
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s potential incentive to remain in Canada due to higher wages
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must be given chance to respond to adverse undisclosed concerns
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of interview and no opportunity to address concerns
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of applicant due to procedural breach
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Undisclosed assumptions about financial incentives and family ties
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No response opportunity provided by visa officer
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and redetermination by another officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Duty of fairness under Canadian administrative law

Crime_Type: Violent Crimes
Mitigating_Factors: State has mechanisms for protection; claimant did not exhaust available resources
Risk_Nature: Non-state actor harm with insufficient state protection claimed
Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on gender and domestic relationship
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to prove lack of state protection
Evidence_Type: Testimony, procedural history, legal framework analysis
